title: Why Fork Flutter? The Birth of Flock
description: In this episode, we dive into the reasons behind the forking of Flutter to create Flock, exploring how this new project aims to solve existing challenges faced by the Flutter community.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Hello and welcome to another episode of 'life is artificial', where we explore the cutting edge of technology, innovation, and what the future could look like.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Today, we’re going to talk about something pretty exciting that's happening in the developer community: a major fork of Flutter, the popular UI toolkit, called Flock. You may have heard some rumblings about this, but I want to take you through the whole story—why Flutter is being forked, what Flock aims to do, and why this might just be the change that the Flutter community needs.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: The news comes from an article titled 'We're Forking Flutter. This is Why,' published by the Flutter Foundation. If you want to check it out, I'll include the link in the episode description. But let’s break it down here together.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: So, first, what is Flutter? Flutter is a UI toolkit created by Google that has gained immense popularity over the years. It started as a mobile toolkit for iOS and Android, then expanded to include web, desktop, and even embedded devices. This means developers can write one codebase and deploy it across multiple platforms. Pretty cool, right?

script.speaker: Host
script.text: But here's where the issue comes in: despite Flutter’s rapid growth, the size of the development team at Google didn't grow enough to keep up. Imagine trying to support millions of developers across all these platforms, with only about 50 people on your team. That’s like having a small town’s worth of firefighters trying to serve an entire country. It’s a tough situation, and the community has started to feel the strain.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: One of the core challenges has been a lack of sufficient labor to address tickets and fix bugs in a timely manner. Many developers have reported that their issues lingered for months, even years, without resolution. This is partly because the Flutter team had its headcount frozen in 2023, and even experienced some layoffs earlier in 2024. This resulted in delays, frustration, and ultimately led some teams to abandon Flutter entirely.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: On top of that, Google's focus shifted towards AI, leading to a deprioritization of the desktop versions of Flutter. Now, the desktop is a huge opportunity for Flutter, as it could provide developers with an all-in-one toolkit for apps across mobile, web, and desktop. But with Google putting desktop on the back burner, it’s been stagnating.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: So, what’s the solution? A group of developers decided to fork Flutter. They call it Flock—like a flock of birds, a community moving together. The idea behind Flock is to take everything great about Flutter and build upon it, adding the features and fixes that the Flutter team at Google can’t or won’t focus on.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: The people behind Flock describe it as 'Flutter+', meaning it’s not intended to divide the community but to enhance what Flutter can do. Flock will stay up to date with the main Flutter codebase, while adding bug fixes and popular features that have been neglected.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Flock also wants to address the labor shortage by recruiting more contributors and making it easier for them to get involved. One of the big pain points for contributing to Flutter has been the lengthy and sometimes frustrating review process. The current Flutter team is stretched too thin—they have to write code, fix bugs, and review contributions. This means that reviews often take a long time, and the process can feel unwelcoming to new contributors.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Flock aims to change that by recruiting a large team of reviewers who are not just willing to tolerate contributions, but to actively facilitate them. They want reviewers who are ready to help contributors cross the finish line, even if it means stepping in to assist with the final tweaks.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: The Flock team is also focusing on optimizing the policies around contributions—making sure that unnecessary bureaucratic steps are removed, and that contributors feel encouraged rather than blocked. They even envision using successful contributions as a way to socially promote more participation from the community.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: So, what does this mean for developers? It means faster bug fixes, quicker feature rollouts, and a more responsive development process. For companies and teams that use Flutter, it means less waiting and less frustration when a bug in Flutter is holding them back.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: But it's important to note that Flock isn’t trying to compete against Flutter—it’s trying to complement it. The Flock team wants to make their fixes and improvements available to Flutter, allowing the Google team to integrate them if and when they choose. This way, Flock users get access to these features right away, without having to wait for Google's timeline.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: And how can you get involved? Well, Flock needs the community to succeed. They’re asking developers to alpha test the fork, become reviewers, and even step up as leads for specific areas of the project. They want this to be a community-driven effort that helps propel Flutter—and now Flock—to new heights.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: It’s a bold move, and one that could potentially redefine the landscape for Flutter developers. If it works, it could set a new standard for how open-source projects scale and evolve. So, if you’re a developer who loves Flutter but has felt the frustrations of its current pace, maybe it’s time to Flock together.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: That’s it for today’s episode. I hope you enjoyed this deep dive into the world of Flutter and Flock. If you’re interested in reading the full article, I’ve linked it in the description. As always, thank you for tuning in to 'life is artificial.' Keep coding, keep innovating, and I’ll catch you in the next episode!
